member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Collection
member.summary: The class Collection contains several utilities performing some basic collection operations (like union, intersection...).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Collection.#ctor
member.summary: Preventing the instantiation of the class.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Collection.Concat(System.Collections.ICollection,System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: Returns a collection resulting from the concatenation from c1 and c2.
member.remarks: The call is performed in O(1) computational time, the concatenated collection is not built explicitly.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Collection.Inter(System.Collections.ICollection,System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: Returns a collection resulting from the mathematical intersection of c1 and c2.

remarks.p: The call is performed in O(c1.Count+c2.Count) and the intersection is built explicitly.
The resulting collection will not contain several identical elements.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Collection.Minus(System.Collections.ICollection,System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: Returns a collection resulting from the subtraction of the items of c2 to the collection c1.
member.remarks: The call is performed in O(c1.Count+c2.Count)

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Collection.Product(System.Collections.ICollection,System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: Returns the cartesian product of the two collections c1 and c2.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Collection.Union(System.Collections.ICollection,System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: Returns a collection resulting from the union of the items of c1 and c2.

remarks.p: The call is performed in O(c1.Count+c2.Count) computational time.
The resulting collection will not contain several identical elements.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Complex
member.summary: Complex numbers class.

remarks.p: The class Complex provides all elementary operations on complex numbers. All the operators +, -, *, /, ==, != are defined in the canonical way. Additional complex trigonometric functions such as , ... are also provided. Note that the Complex structures has two special constant values and .
In order to avoid possible ambiguities resulting from a Complex(double, double) constructor, the static methods and are provided instead.
Since there is no canonical order among the complex numbers, Complex does not implement IComparable but several lexicographic IComparer implementations are provided, see , and .
For mathematical details about complex numbers, please have a look at the Wikipedia

member.summary: Represents the infinity value. This field is constant.
member.remarks: The semantic associated to this value is a Complex of infinite real and imaginary part. If you need more formal complex number handling (according to the Riemann Sphere and the extended complex plane C*, or using directed infinity) please check out the alternative MathNet.PreciseNumerics and MathNet.Symbolics packages instead.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.NormalDistribution
member.summary: Pseudo-random generation of normal distributed deviates.

remarks.para:
For details about this distribution, see
Wikipedia - Normal distribution.
This implementation is based on the Box-Muller algorithm for generating random deviates with a normal distribution.

For details of the algorithm, see
Numerical recipes in C (chapter 7)
pdf: f(x) = 1/(s*sqrt(2*Pi))*exp(-(x-m)^2/(2*s^2)); m = mu (location), s = sigma (scale)

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.StandardDistribution
member.summary: Pseudo-random generation of standard distributed deviates.

remarks.para:
For details about this distribution, see
Wikipedia - Normal distribution.
This implementation is based on the Box-Muller algorithm for generating random deviates with a normal distribution.

For details of the algorithm, see
Numerical recipes in C (chapter 7)

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.ArbitraryDistribution
member.summary: Non-uniform discrete random distribution.

remarks.p: The class DiscreteGenerator provides integers deviates for any arbitrary (finite) distribution.
The probability Pr(x) for any integer x is proportional to DiscreteGenerator[x].
See the chapter three of the book Non-uniform variate Generation from Luc Devroye.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.GeometricDistribution
member.summary: Provides generation of geometric distributed random numbers.

The geometric distribution generates only discrete numbers.
The implementation bases upon information presented on Wikipedia - Geometric distribution and the implementation in the Communication Networks Class Library.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.ZipfDistribution
member.summary: Pseudo-random generator of Zipf distributed deviates.

remarks.p: The density of the continuous Zipf distribution is defined on [1, +infinity), the density is proportional to x^s where s > 1 is the skew.
See the Wikipedia for more information about Zipf distribution.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.RandomSources.AdditiveLaggedFibonacciRandomSource
member.summary: Represents a Additive Lagged Fibonacci pseudo-random number generator.
member.remarks: The type bases upon the implementation in the Boost Random Number Library. It uses the modulus 232 and by default the "lags" 418 and 1279, which can be adjusted through the associated and properties. Some popular pairs are presented on Wikipedia - Lagged Fibonacci generator.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.CholeskyDecomposition
member.summary: Cholesky Decomposition.
member.remarks: For a symmetric, positive definite matrix A, the Cholesky decomposition is an lower triangular matrix L so that A = L*L'. If the matrix is not symmetric or positive definite, the constructor returns a partial decomposition and sets an internal flag that may be queried by the property.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.EigenvalueDecomposition
member.summary: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a real matrix.
member.remarks: If A is symmetric, then A = V*D*V' where the eigenvalue matrix D is diagonal and the eigenvector matrix V is orthogonal. I.e. A = V.Multiply(D.Multiply(V.Transpose())) and V.Multiply(V.Transpose()) equals the identity matrix. If A is not symmetric, then the eigenvalue matrix D is block diagonal with the real eigenvalues in 1-by-1 blocks and any complex eigenvalues, lambda + i*mu, in 2-by-2 blocks, [lambda, mu; -mu, lambda]. The columns of V represent the eigenvectors in the sense that A*V = V*D, i.e. A.Multiply(V) equals V.Multiply(D). The matrix V may be badly conditioned, or even singular, so the validity of the equation A = V*D*Inverse(V) depends upon V.cond().

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.LUDecomposition
member.summary: LU Decomposition.
member.remarks: For an m-by-n matrix A with m >= n, the LU decomposition is an m-by-n unit lower triangular matrix L, an n-by-n upper triangular matrix U, and a permutation vector pivot of length m so that A(piv,:) = L*U. If m < n, then L is m-by-m and U is m-by-n. The LU decomposition with pivoting always exists, even if the matrix is singular, so the constructor will never fail. The primary use of the LU decomposition is in the solution of square systems of simultaneous linear equations. This will fail if IsNonSingular() returns false.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.QRDecomposition
member.summary: QR Decomposition.
member.remarks:
For an m-by-n matrix A with m >= n, the QR decomposition is an m-by-n orthogonal matrix Q and an n-by-n upper triangular matrix R so that A = Q*R.
The QR decomposition always exists, even if the matrix does not have full rank, so the constructor will never fail. The primary use of the QR decomposition is in the least squares solution of non-square systems of simultaneous linear equations. This will fail if IsFullRank() returns false.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.SingularValueDecomposition
member.summary: Singular Value Decomposition.

remarks.p: For an m-by-n matrix A with m >= n, the singular value decomposition is an m-by-n orthogonal matrix U, an n-by-n diagonal matrix S, and an n-by-n orthogonal matrix V so that A = U*S*V'.
The singular values, sigma[k] = S[k, k], are ordered so that sigma[0] >= sigma[1] >= ... >= sigma[n-1].
The singular value decomposition always exists, so the constructor will never fail. The matrix condition number and the effective numerical rank can be computed from this decomposition.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Quaternion.Abs
member.summary: G ets the standard euclidean length |q| = sqrt(||q||) of the quaternion q: the square root of the sum of the squares of the four components. Q may then be represented as q = r*(cos(phi) + u * sin(phi)) = r*exp(phi*u) where u is the unit vector and phi the argument of q.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Quaternion.Norm

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Quaternion.Arg
member.summary: Gets the argument phi = arg(q) of the quaternion q, such that q = r*(cos(phi) + u * sin(phi)) = r*exp(phi*u) where r is the absolute and u the unit vector of q.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Quaternion.IsUnitQuaternion
member.summary: True if the quaternion q is of lenght |q| = 1.
member.remarks: To normalize a quaternion to a length of 1, use the method. All unit quaternions form a 3-sphere.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.SampleList
member.summary: SampleList is a sorted list in ascending order for discrete function samples x=f(t) or value pairs (t,x). Multiple values x for the same t are replaced with the mean.
member.remarks: This list is designed for rare additions and removals only and is slow when adding items in not-ascending order. Better fill it directly in the constructor.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SampleList.Locate(System.Double)
member.summary: Find the index i of a sample near t such that t[i] <= t <= t[i+1].
member.returns: The lower bound index of the interval, -1 or Size-1 if out of bounds.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SampleList.Locate(System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Find the index i of a sample near t such that t[i] <= t <= t[i+1].
member.remarks: This method is faster if the expected index is near nearIndex (compared to the list size) but may be slower otherwise (worst case: factor 2 slower, best case: log2(n) faster).
member.returns: The lower bound index of the interval, -1 or Size-1 if out of bounds.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.Factorial(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the factorial (n!) of an integer number > 0. Consider using instead.
member.returns: A value value! for value > 0
member.remarks: If you need to multiply or divide various such factorials, consider using the logarithmic version instead so you can add instead of multiply and subtract instead of divide, and then exponentiate the result using . This will also completely circumvent the problem that factorials easily become very large.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.BinomialCoefficient(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the binomial coefficient of n and k as a double precision number.
member.remarks: If you need to multiply or divide various such coefficients, consider using the logarithmic version instead so you can add instead of multiply and subtract instead of divide, and then exponentiate the result using .

member.summary: Returns the natural logarithm of the binomial coefficient of n and k as a double precision number.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.GammaRegularized(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the regularized lower incomplete gamma function P(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) * int(exp(-t)t^(a-1),t=0..x) for real a > 0, x > 0.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.Beta(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the Euler Beta function of real valued z > 0, w > 0. Beta(z,w) = Beta(w,z).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.BetaLn(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the natural logarithm of the Euler Beta function of real valued z > 0, w > 0. BetaLn(z,w) = BetaLn(w,z).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.IncompleteBetaRegularized(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Obsolete. Please use BetaRegularized instead, with the same parameters (method was renamed).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.BetaRegularized(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the regularized lower incomplete beta function I_x(a,b) = 1/Beta(a,b) * int(t^(a-1)*(1-t)^(b-1),t=0..x) for real a > 0, b > 0, 1 >= x >= 0.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.Erf(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the error function erf(x) = 2/sqrt(pi) * int(exp(-t^2),t=0..x)

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.ErfInverse(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the inverse error function erf^-1(x).

remarks.p: The algorithm uses a minimax approximation by rational functions and the result has a relative error whose absolute value is less than 1.15e-9.
See the page for more details.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Accumulator
member.summary: The Accumulator provides online algorithms to computes the first statistical moments and their derivatives.

remarks.p: The Accumulator provides memory efficient online algorithms to compute the first statistical moments (mean, variance) and their derivatives (sigma, error estimate).
The Accumulator is not thread safe.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Transformations.TransformationConvention.AsymmetricScaling
member.summary: Only scale by 1/N in the inverse direction; No scaling in forward direction.

member.summary: Inverse integrand exponent (forward: positive sign; inverse: negative sign).

member.summary: Don't scale at all (neither on forward nor on inverse transformation).

member.summary: Universal; Symmetric scaling and common exponent (used in Maple).

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Transformations.TransformationConvention.Matlab
member.summary: Only scale by 1/N in the inverse direction; No scaling in forward direction (used in Matlab). [= AsymmetricScaling]

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Transformations.TransformationConvention.NumericalRecipes
member.summary: Inverse integrand exponent; No scaling at all (used in all Numerical Recipes based implementations). [= InverseExponent | NoScaling]
